chapter.title: Getting started
chapter.para: This chapter will show you how to get started with Hibernate Validator - the reference implementation (RI) of Bean Validation. For the following quickstart you need:

listitem.para: A functioning Internet connection (Maven has to download all required libraries)

A properly configured remote repository. Add the following to your settings.xml: <repositories> <repository> <id>jboss</id> <url>http://repository.jboss.com/maven2</url> <releases> <enabled>true</enabled> </releases> <snapshots> <enabled>false</enabled> </snapshots> </repository> </repositories>More information about settings.xml can be found in the Maven Local Settings Model.

section.title: Setting up a new Maven project
section.para: Start by creating new Maven project using the Maven archetype plugin as follows:

When presented with the list of available archetypes in the JBoss Maven Repository select the hibernate-validator-quickstart-archetype. After downloading all dependencies confirm the settings by just pressing enter. Maven will create your project in the directory beanvalidation-gettingstarted. Change into this directory and run:
mvn testYou should see some compiling and testing action taking place. Time to look at the actual code.

section.title: Applying constraints to a model class
section.para: Open the project in the IDE of your choice and have a look at the class Car:

note.para: Eclipse users can type mvn eclipse:eclipse to create a standard Eclipse project configuration or they use the M2Eclipse plugin. NetBeans and Intellij have great built-in Maven support.

listitem.para: licensePlate shall never be null and must be between 2 and 14 characters long

section.para: To perform a validation of these constraints, we use a Validator instance. Let's have a look at the CarTest class:

example.title: Class CarTest showing validation examples

section.para: In the setUp() method we get a Validator instance from the ValidatorFactory. A Validator instance is thread-safe and may be reused multiple times, therefore we store it as field of our test class. We can use the validator now to validate the different car instances in the test methods.

The validate() method returns a set of ConstraintViolation objects, which we can iterate in order to see which validation errors occurred. The first three test methods show some expected constraint violations:

listitem.para: The @NotNull constraint on manufacturer is violated in manufacturerIsNull()
The @Size constraint on licensePlate is violated in licensePlateTooShort()
The @Min constraint on seatCount is violated in seatCountTooLow()

section.para: If the object could be validated successfully, validate() returns an empty set.

Note that we only use classes from the package javax.validation from the Bean Validation API. As we don't reference any classes of the RI directly, it would be no problem to switch to another implementation of the API, should that need arise.

section.title: Where to go next?
section.para: That concludes our 5 minute tour through the world of the Bean Validation RI.
